args: In my search for a new occupation, I paid a visit\nto the King of Grams, with whom I had a rapport\nbefore the fall of Lefkos.
He listened to the tale of its downfall with a\nsympathetic ear, then gifted me with work\nand a dwelling.
We're honored to have you on as a special\nadvisor, sir. There are no end to the heroic\ntales of the Blazewolf Gatov!
Pray let that be the end of flattery. I am\nnot so great a man as you would paint me.
His Majesty informs me that the task of\nkeeping the streets of Grams safe falls to\nthe Church's Templars. Is this correct?
In truth, all de facto power in Grams\nrests with the Church of Ilia.
Yet a kingdom can't well be without SOME\nform of ＂official＂ national defense, so...\nWell, here we are.
(So to put a finer point on it, the royal\nguard are strictly ornamental.)
You're only fresh arrived to Grams and\nmust have many questions. It would be\nan honor to be your guide, sir.
I would appreciate it. Also, I wonder if I\nmight impose upon you by asking my\ndaughter along for the tour as well?
Do try to stay close, Sheila.
The large building just beyond is the\nAugust Cathedral. Only those of elevated\nstation in the Canon are permitted inside.
The Canon is the Church's hierarchy of\nsocial standing, yes? I hear those at its top\nenjoy considerable power and freedom.

Indeed, sir. According to the Church,
the Canon serves as incentive to motivate
the people of Grams into living virtuous
lives of civic contribution.

Yet I understand the principle method for
raising one's stature is monetary donation.
Does that not limit who is able to ascend
through the ranks?
It might behoove you not to pose that\nquestion too loudly, sir.
Even as His Majesty's guest, you run the\nrisk of being branded a heretic by the\nChurch and expelled from the city.
(Hmm. If that is this kingdom's way,\nperhaps it is not my place to interfere.)
...Sir? I do not see your daughter.
There you are! I thought I asked you\nto stay close, young lady. Next time...

Heavens above, but where ARE we?!
We can't be more than a few streets from
that lavish boulevard, yet this place is a
squalid hellhole...
These are the slums, sir, where those\nwithout the means to live elsewhere come.\nLoners and drifters, most of them.
It's midday, and yet light barely reaches\nthese streets. Filth and refuse abound,\nand the buildings are in terrific disrepair.
Salvation for all in equal measure is a\npillar of the Ilian Church's teachings.\nAre they not aware of the conditions here?
The differences in privilege that accrue to\nthose of diverse stations in the Canon has\nalways been met with some...resistance.
The slums are left to rot as a means to\nease the frustrations of the common folk.
＂At least I'm better off than them...＂ To sell\na people on mediocrity, give them a true\nunderclass to measure themselves against.
In truth, His Majesty is also greatly\ntroubled by the state of the slums.
But so long as the Church holds all the\ntrue power here in Grams, I fear there is\nlittle we can do.

(These poor people... Abandoned by the
Church, they cannot even hope to claw
their way to a better life by elevating their
place in the Canon.)
(Those living here do so under the yoke of\ncrushing injustice. There's a cold logic to\nthe system, aye—but an inhuman one.)
There's a young girl looking this way.
Um, mister soldier, sir? There's a hole in\nthe big wall. Can you fix it? Please?
I expect she means the outer wall, sir.\nThis area is located at the city's edge.
We've tried fixing it time and again, but\nthere's no one here what can do it right,\nso it keeps breaking apart.
Cracks in the outer wall run the risk of\npermitting fiends entry. We must call for\na master mason at once.
The city's fortifications also fall under the\nChurch's authority. Let us relay word of\nthis to them.
...We've confirmed the reported crack in\nthe outer wall.
But it's too small for a fiend to pass\nthrough. There's no need for intervention.
Yet it will be too late to intervene once it\ngrows larger. Surely it would be best to\naddress the matter now?
...Gatov, was it? You seem new here,\nso let me explain something to you.

The Church makes the decisions in Grams.
The Church pays for its upkeep and repair.
And the royal guard knows enough to keep
its damn mouth shut.
Be that as it may, we cannot ignore the\nrisk of fiends gaining entry to the city.
Any further protest will be taken as a\nusurpation of Church authority. Are you so\neager to lose your post and be exiled?
The royal court does not have the luxury of\nrefusing a demand from the Church, sir.\nI beg that you relent.

(I find this administration's willingness
to ignore the plight of its least fortunate
and accept unneeded casualties highly
questionable. However...)
...Perhaps I spoke out of place, sir.\nYour ways are new to me, and I apologize\nif I caused any offense.
Just see you remember your place!
Are they gonna fix the wall, mister?
I'm sorry, child. I fear I cannot help you.
Dinner is ready, Sheila. Let's eat.
(Being special advisor to a purely symbolic\nforce doesn't entail much work, so if\nSheila ever needs me, I can be there.)
(Considering her needs, settling here\nin Grams makes a good deal of sense.)

(And though I may have my qualms,
I'll need to abide by the city's ways—
even if it means turning a blind eye
now and again.)
...No appetite? You aren't eating.\nAre you feeling unwell?
From that day on, Sheila took to remaining in her\nroom. Unsure of what had brought the sad tinge to\nher expression, I could only look on and worry.

＂My dear friend Aurelius,
Apologies for the long silence. Sadly,
I have more to tell you than one letter
can possibly hold.＂
＂I have tales of my new home in Grams,\nand the injustices I have witnessed here.\nAnd of course, there is Sheila.＂
＂She has me at a loss, old friend.\nHonestly, I would welcome any insights\nyou might have in the matter.＂
＂As a father, what am I to do?＂
